comment.narrative: (2013) Project is in re-lunching phase with limited staff, Socotra in the way to become governorate with new realities. low coordination between different authorities and limited use of Socotra conservation zoning plan and low involvement of NGOs in decision making and conservation activities , local community has very limited benefits from biodiversity, however interest on Socotra increased with several international projects currently working on the island.
21 community development initiatives granted to local NGOs in Socotra.
80% of the local NGOs that received grants completed the work
Local communities NGO capacities enhanced to contribute in biodiversity conservation and sustainable use of natural resources.

All NGOs who received grants completed the work and their capacities enhanced to contribute in biodiversity conservation and sustainable use of natural resources to support local community livelihoods and generate income opportunities for the local vulnerable growth while at the same time reserved the island diversity and protect the environment of the island.

description.narrative:
Biodiversity management considerations are mainstreamed effectively into the current process of decentralizing governance for development on the Socotra archipelago
Sustainable natural resources management and protection of Socotra Archipelago ecosystems

Mainstreaming Impacts
Socotra spatial plans incorporates biodiversity information provided by EPASCDP
Number of public and private sector developments in breach of the spatial plan
Four new MPAs established and management plans developed

comment.narrative:
Spatial planning system is not effective
Three MPAs established and operational

Compliance with all spatial planning decisions by Island Wide and District Administrations
Seven MPAs fully operational

Establishment of Socotra integrated coastal zone management board legal offices governor decision to research department to be responsible of mainstreaming biodiversity consideration to governorate strategic planning Capacity building to governorate offices in GIS system based on environmental data and the project help in solving some environmental issues such as eradication of new introduction of Indian house crow and introduction of beehives The project also becomes more clear after reviewing of his loge frame with help on international parttime technical advisor

description.narrative: Local Governance Support

Local Governance Impacts
Island wide administration operational and working on integrated manner with local national and international stakeholders

comment.narrative:
Limited coordination between multiple individual Ministries deconcentrated branches of central Authorities from the Governorate Local District Councils powerful individuals private sector initiatives
District level local authorities are not operating in an integrated manner and with weak capacities in mobilising resources managing public expenditures and promoting local economic development

New Island Wide local governance structure approved by end of Year 2 with appropriate coordination mechanism advocacy in place central local
Single strategic planning body at the local level undertaking integrated planning on Socotra by end of Year 3
New local district authority structures in Socotra aligned with national decentralisation strategy and working in an integrated manner with Island wide governance structures
District local administration with enhanced capacities to mobilise resources manage public expenditures promote local economic development and tourism in line with relevant international commitments World Heritage Status

Management Development Research and Training Division MDRT within governor office partly plays the role of strategic planning unit governor decision The divisions also representing the governorate in supervising the information counter Currently there is still a discussion with stakeholders for the best way of integrating biodiversity consideration into strategic planning The National Integrated coastal zone management board established and will enhance strategic planning and coordination Developing the financial capacity of new governorate of Socotra training course entitled Prepare the budget for Socotra Archipelago and its Environmental Indicators hold in EPA Socotra with 40 trainees from different government agencies More work is the creating strategic planning unit and it functionality

description.narrative: Mainstreaming Tools Provided

Mainstreaming Impacts
Use of mainstreaming tools provided by the project by strategic planners

comment.narrative: Conservation Zoning Plan only used by EPA

Strategic Planning Unit to prepare necessary tools to mainstream environmental consideration into Island wide planning decision making processes
Regulations that mandate the local administration to use the planning tools and the EPASCDPs data as part of the Strategic Planning Units development of integrated programmes

Focusing on rising awareness of different stakeholders on Socotra about environmental laws and legislations and CZP the project holds 2 workshops with more than 70 participants discussed the conservation zoning plan first with fisherman and second with local authority The governor minister of fishery and other government directors attend those workshops Conservation zoning plan maps have been redesigned printed and distributed to several target groups includes government offices schools NGOs hotels and tourism agencies Awareness campaigns with local authorities fishermen and other associations and school students continue through individuals and group meetings reached more than 400 individuals Conservation zoning plan document have been distributed to participants and also have been distributed to other officials through MDRTD staff in total more than 60 copies have been distributed The national legal advisor started in reviewing existing national biodiversity mainstreaming tools and its compatibility with national laws and legislations As part of integrating biodiversity conservation considerations to development decision making

Number of NGOsCBOs community development associations on Socotra involved in biodiversity management

comment.narrative: 1 NGO actively involved
20 NGOsCBOs active by end of Year 4 involved

Targeting awareness of local NGOsCBOs 27 fishermen associations have been targeted for awareness workshop about CZP women association celebrate the world wetland day one community group celebrate world wildlife day
Ensuring highlighting key biodiversity conservation priorities 3 campaigns have been organized first celebration of world wildlife day focusing on biodiversity and ecotourism more than 100 celebrated the events with films on open air second celebration of national environmental day through giving lectures in the school about important of biodiversity more than 200 students reached and third invitation of researchers giving lectures in the university about caves archeology rock art more than 70 students participated

description.narrative: Project Management
Delivering of activities and funds in a timely effective and transparent manner

comment.narrative: NA

Project activities carried out in a timely efficient and transparent manner allowing for justifiable contingencies
Work Plan approved in inception phase

Due to political unrest the board meeting have not done except one virtual meeting through internet communication Annual and quarterly work plans and budgets have been prepared and the annual report and quarterly progress reports have been submitted The project has filled all necessary ereporting requirements such as Atlas intranet PIR and format of quarterly reporting The project also submits all financial requirements work plans budget plans and risk action plan Other short reporting has been submitted such as communication strategy school environmental clubs and success stories The project indicators such as NGOs current situation have been reviewed ToRs for the recruitment of additional staff as well as of consultants have been drafted and advertised 2 national consultants recruited and one international parttime technical advisor for short period for helping the project team especially in reporting

description.narrative: Strengthened Link Between Biodiversity Local Benefits and Conservation Outcomes

Higher revenues that local administration derive natural resources from exploitative assets of the Island
No of sustainable private initiatives including SMEs and higher income for local communities resulting from sustainable trade of biological specimens

comment.narrative: Limited benefits for rural communities

Regulations and enforcement in place to allow private communal initiatives to export biological specimens under certification
Regulations to allow local authorities to mobilize revenues from tourist activities either from incoming tourist or through service providers and guidelines that enable local communities particularly in rural areas to benefit from these activities
Regulations to allow GoY and local administration in Socotra to benefit from existing market on biodiversity property rights

First under indicator 1 there are two indicators and both have been revised by PTA during projects logframe revision first Higher revenues that local administration derives from exploitative natural resource assets of the Island second No of sustainable private initiatives including SMEs and higher income for local communities resulting from sustainable use of biodiversity
The capacity building program which has been submitted includes five training themes organization management sustainability governance and environmental protection this training targeted NGOsCBOs but also SMEs and will help them on writing projects proposals effectively participate in CBNRM and creating and implementing protected areas management plans Implementing the training program will help the NGOs CBOs and community to understand financial mechanisms for visitors tax and protected areas entry fees For the first indicator there will be two main activities visitors tax mechanisms and protected areas entry fees these activities will be implemented with support of national legal advisor The second indicator will includes four activities awareness ecotourism carrying capacity CBNRM and supporting projects proposals Will do this on a competitive basis to simulate real life scenario and apply skills learnt in proposal writing training as part of institutional capacity building program Applications should contain both biodiversity conservation and biodiversityfriendly livelihood components and be linked to GEFSGP

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. The Land and Dismissals Commissions have capacity to aggregate and dissegrate cases and protect documentation. 2. The Transitional Justice Woorking Group of the National Dialogue Conference has capacity to define appropriate recommendations regarding transitional justice and to improve TJ legislation 3. Representatives of excluded and marginalized communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens of southern governorates, victims, tribesmen etc. included in consultation process on transitional justice and national reconciliation 4. Staff of MoLA gained knowledge on transitional justice in general and truth commissions in particular and what is important to create relevant laws and by-laws.

comment.narrative: 1. Draft Law on Transitional Justice and National Reconciliation is not adopted 2. The Land and Dismissals Commissions do not have capacity to achieve their mandates. 3. Inexistance of consultations on transitional justice. It is widely percieved that some communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens from Souther Governorates, victims etc. are excluded from societal processes. 4. CSOs, representatives of government and society in general do not have knowledge on TJ.

A plan was developed for the four District Facilitation Teams (DFTs) to conduct assessment to identify the needs of office equipment at 14 districts. The assessment of the equipment needs and identification of potential members of core teams have been taking place from the last week of September to the second week of October. â€¢ Established five DFTs, which consist of six to seven people in four governorates (Hadramout, Hajjah, Taiz, and Socotra). Total number of DFTs members are 32 and 8 are female. â€¢ Each District Facilitation Team includes at least two Civil Society Organisations representatives recommended by UNFPA. â€¢ Official launching events took place with the Ministry of Local Administration (MoLA) and the Governors in Taiz and Hadramout. â€¢ Formation of 14 Core Teams will be conducted in October The process of the district planning has been completed for the year of 2014. The Peace and Transition Support Project (PTSP) started collecting the plans developed by the District Governments in 14 target districts. The review of the plan and consultation will be done in November and December. Options of grant systems have been identified. Discussions with the MoLA, Ministry of Finance (MoF) and Central Bank are on-going to identify the most efficient ways to channel grants to the districts using the government budget allocation system. An agreement for the grant system would be signed upon the district plan review and identification of priority projects in participatory manner at the district.
Initial discussions took place with MoLA in confirming the area of support that MoLA would need. The review and preparation of legal framework for local governance would be launched upon the first draft of constitution is available (the draft constitution is expected to be available in November).

- While UNDP has proposed to the Government of the Republic of France to support 10 villages in Khadir district, Taizz Governorate, Social Fund for Development (SFD) has succeeded in establishment of 15 VCCs. In the target 15 villages, capacity of VCC members and local authorities on community-based analysis (using social, resource service and opportunity maps) was developed. As a result, 15 community-based participatory analysis and development reports were prepared.
- Based on the community-based analysis and development plan, a list of community initiatives was developed in each respective community (i.e. 15 lists of community initiatives). Out of the list, UNDP in partnership with SFD will support implementation of the selected community initiatives in the 4th quarter. It is a condition that the community will contribute minimum 50% of the total required community initiativesâ€™ budget. Additionally, communities are encouraged to conduct self-initiatives in order to nurture self-reliance. Self-initiatives are not financially supported by the project but itâ€™s implemented with voluntary contribution by community resources. In total 110 self-initiatives were implemented in 15 villages in the third quarter.
- The project focuses on sub-district level local capacity development and the results were indicated by the following deliverables: 15 community-based analyses; and 15 community-based participatory development plans. The deliverables were verified with the following evidences. Additionally, pictures from the target communities demonstrate participatory processes.
â€¢ 15 participatory development reports including lists of community initiatives â€¢ 15 community-based analyses, which consist of demographic data; social maps, resource, service and opportunity maps; strengths and weakness analysis; and needs assessment of disabled persons.

Between January and March 2016, YEEP has created 166 direct employment opportunities for youth, including 27% of women, through the capitalisation of micro-social businesses that contribute to social impact in addition to generating income. Youth also benefited from improved business and life skills through training, coaching and business advisory services provided, that will improve their business resilience. A MoU was signed with the Arab Association in Singapore and a Goodwill Ambassador appointed, Dr Saad ben Taleb, former Minister of Industry and Trade, to promote the Yemen Our Home initiative in Southeast Asia amongst the Diaspora community. Similarly, partnerships have been concluded with Sabafon to directly fund the establishment of a youth-run social business in Sanaâ€™a responding to local health needs and outreach to associations/companies pursued to identify areas of mutual interests for in-kind or financial contributions. Through technical assistance, the Business Support Centre established in 2015 finalised its work plan to expand its operations and strategic relevance through prospective studies and developing a one-stop-shop oriented solutions centre for aspiring and existing young entrepreneurs.
During Q2, two projects were funded through the Yemen Our Home initiative by SabaFon and Al Kuraimi with preparations led towards their implementation. the BSC continued to run its programme in Sana'a to support entrepreneurs through innovation-oriented workshops such as the Yemen Business Breakfast.
- At least one project on social business is developed and supported through Diaspora and private sector partnership. â€ƒ

20 midwives were trained in businesses management and community mapping. They have also received refresh training in reproductive health and received specific equipment to start their own private clinics. Other 12 trained midwives also received extra equipment supporting their established clinicsâ€.

comment.narrative: N/A

Indicators: quality of dairy products improved Targets: 70% of beneficiary women producing higher quality Yemeni dairy
â€¢ Activity 2: Indicators: # of MSMEs established through skills development and capitalisation Targets: 250
â€¢ Activity 3: Indicators: # of vulnerable households that improve their living conditions through community-based cash for work scheme Targets: 800

The project provided direct economic opportunities to 2,423 beneficiaries in Taizz Governorate, reaching 8,757 indirect beneficiaries, to promote economic self-reliance responding to the socioeconomic needs that arose from the outbreak of the crisis in March 2015. 615 women from Taizz Governorate established their micro businesses in cheese, laban and women-only professions. In the dairy value chain, over 95% of cheese and laban businesses now meet health and hygiene standards in acceptable production locations, and similarly an overwhelming majority of the women entrepreneurs are willing to improve and expand their businesses. 165 midwives have established new clinics in rural districts of Taizz, to improve access to pregnant and lactating women to these services. 1,808 individuals including 48% of women have benefitted from emergency employment opportunities to stabilise their livelihoods and build assets for their communities. A total of 79,551 work-days were generated to rapidly inject cash and enable vulnerable beneficiaries to meet basic needs. Over 56 hectares of agricultural terraces were rehabilitated, 1.2kms of irrigation canals were rehabilitated/constructed, along with five wells and 217 latrines were constructed.

comment.narrative: Numerous NGOs mainly based in Sana, weak capacity in general and absence in many key geographical areas.

1: Governorate based NGOs (GB NGOs ) in priority conflict affected governorates have the capacity to implement high quality conflict sensitive projects
2: GBNGOs implement peacebuilding and conflict sensitive interventions in target areas
3: An online pool of accredited GBNGOs will be established to facilitate partnerships of GBNGOs with the government, national and international development and humanitarian agencies.
4: Management and monitoring of the project

1- Following the agreement with the donor to resume the project activities, with a new expiration date (December 31, 2016), the project team made a great progress starting with revising the plan to training 60 NGOs that already received basic training (project and finance management and monitoring and evaluation) in previous phase of the project. The training focused on strengthening conflict sensitive approaches to (i) humanitarian assistance, (ii) early recovery and (iii) conflict-sensitive development. Activity Result 1.1: Conduct capacity assessment and selection of GBNGOs for the training Our implementing Partner Humanitarian Forum Yemen assessed 155 NGOs in the six targeted governorates to identify the most qualified/active NGOs and their needs for training in each governorate. Activity Result 1.2: Develop and print training modules and manuals Consultants have been hired to develop training manuals on the above three thematic areas. The training manuals have been produced and tested through one-day workshop with the trainers. The manuals have been enriched by the national NGOs experience in two trainings organized for 60 NGOs from 6 governorates (Sana'a, Saddah, Hajjah, Taiz, Aden, and Abyan). Activity Result 1.3: Deliver comprehensive accredited training programme on core skills in conflict-sensitive development, humanitarian areas and early recovery Based on the assessment, 60 NGOs from the targeted governorates were selected to participate in the training. A 12-day training has been developed by our implementing partners and delivered. A total of 130 participants (2 from each NGO) were brought to Sanaa in two groups and received the training between September 24 and October 21. description.narrative: Human rights affairs

1- # people (IDPs, returnees, conflict-affected Communities, women and girls etc.) who receive psychosocial and legal services 2- # people witnesses/victims of HRV (IDPs, returnees, conflict-affected Communities, women and girls etc.) interviewed

comment.narrative:
- Grants to CSOs to implement activities (documentation of human rights violations and provision of psychosocial support) 1,000
- Grant to UN Women, to document violations against women and girls victims of war and SGBV and provide psychosocial support to them (900)

From the start of the project UNDP built the capacities of CSOs to document and report human rights violations and provide psychosocial support to victims of war and other people in need. 14 NGOs were contracted in the targeted governorates to implement the project activities.
In addition, UNDP partnered with UN Women in order to implement activities specifically focusing on women and girls victims of war and sexual and gender based violence (SGBV). Implementing partners executed activities in the following governorates: Aden, Abyan, Taizz, Ibb, Lahj, Albayda, Ad-Dhale, Saâ€™ada, Hajjah, and Sanaâ€™a. Due to a large number of women and girls internally displaced by the conflict, UN Women expanded its activities to Amran and Hadramawt Governorates. Districts, beneficiaries and field partners have been chosen according to conflict prevalence. For that purpose, implementing partners relied on first-hand resources located in the area of incidents, NGO networks, individuals, media reports etc. NGOs visited the locations of incidents and victims, hospitals, refugee camps and other related places to collect first-hand information through interviews with survivors, members of the victimsâ€™ families, eyewitnesses, medical staff, IDPs etc. Information about the intervention spread within and among targeted communities and built trust with contracted NGOs which prompted for witnesses, survivors and victimsâ€™ families in high numbers to visit premises of the implementing partners. However, due to political and security reasons the protection partners have not been able to implement more intensive outreach-related and visibility activities, due to sensitivity of activities and open threats from various armed factions. This was particularly related to the northern governorates (Saâ€™ada, Hajjah, Sanaâ€™a and Taiz), but also to the Southern Governorates. Some activities were planned, such as reporting about human rights violations and promo-TV/radio-spots, but they could not be launched,

The objective of the project is to improve the living conditions of the population of Aden by clearing affected areas of debris, managing solid waste and supporting women-led activities through cash for work.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Emergency employment jobs

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
- Volume of debris, rubble and solid waste collected and removed - Number of work-days created through emergency employment

comment.narrative: - limited debris, rubble, solid waste collection and removal in the targeted areas - no emergency employment provided in the targeted areas
- 22,000 tons of debris, rubble and solid waste collected and removed - 57,860 work-days created through emergency employment

During Q2, 360 beneficiaries (including 210 women) have already benefited from direct livelihoods support in emergency employment (cash for work) and vocational training. The project was launched in June 2016 and as of 30 June 2016, collected 66 tons of solid waste from the street of Daar Saad in Aden City generating 3,000 work days for beneficiaries. Site locations for the debris removal intervention have been identified in consultation with local partners and authorities, and a private contractor has been selected to lead the safe removal and disposal of 55,000 tons in the next quarter. The specific needs of women affected by the crisis have been recognised and 160 female beneficiaries completed a vocational training programme in areas of high-market demand to improve their skills, such as carpentry, plumbing, hairdressing or mobile phone maintenance amongst others. Cash-for-work tailored for women will be initiated on 16 July focusing on Crater and provide an additional 10,560 work days to generate income. Partnerships have been concluded with local NGOs acting as implementing partners (Millennium Development Foundation and Tadhamon Association), as well as the Hygiene Fund, local authorities, Public Works office, and other local stakeholders to participate in the project implementation.
- 39,724 tons of generated debris/rubble removed; - 19,714 work-days created through emergency employment.
39,742 tons of generated debris/rubble were collected and removed.

first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Community livelihoods and productive assets are improved to strengthen resilience and economic self-reliance

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1- 100 Community resilience plans are developed. 2- At least 14,000 vulnerable and food insecure individuals indirectly benefiting from emergency income generating revenues that provides immediate income 3- At least 21,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance. 4- 28,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from technical and economic capacities built on agriculture value chains

comment.narrative:
Limited entrepreneurial pathways available in rural (remote) areas for affected/vulnerable groups
Business associations/economic institutions have a limited technical and operational engagement in enterprise recovery

At least 21,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance
Completion of a business capacity assessment targeting two business association to define capacity development response

Preparatory work to set up local partnerships was undertaken during Q2 and two implementing partners were identified for the implementation of the 3x6 approach: SDF (Hajjah, Hodeidah Governorates) and FAF (Abyan Governorate). Contracting and implementation in the field will be finalized in the next quarter, including the finalization of the Lahj contracting. A market assessment was initiated in Hajjah and Hodeidah to identify micro-social business opportunities for the 3x6 beneficiaries. Findings as well as Lahj and Abyan results will be consolidated in a report in the next quarter with dissemination workshops at the local level involving stakeholders, including the business trainers to link the market assessment outcomes with the content of the business training. A business capacity assessment was also launched to review existing and desired capacities of the Hodeidah Chamber of Commerce and Yemen Business Club in Aden to support crisis-affected SMEs. Two consultants were contracted and finalized their methodology. The assessment will be completed in the next quarter.

- At least 9,800 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance. - 1,400 beneficiaries are engaged in cash for work activities and enrolled in business and life and skills training and 800 business created. - Two business associationsâ€™ capacity needs assessed and capacity gaps addressed through capacity building programmes.

comment.narrative:
- Map rural energy insecurity gap in the targeted governorates

- Socio-Economic and Energy Assessment was conducted in Hajjah, Lahej, Hodaida and Abyan. The assessment objective is to collect and review available information and data on the socio-economic context, the basic social services and communal facilities and the key productive community assets in the targeted districts. The assessment also identified the most vulnerable and energy insecure groups and communities, energy gaps and needs for sustainable operation of prioritized key services of the social services and communal facilities.
-Short and medium terms priorities have been identified with stakeholders for health units and schools. - Design of technical installation of solar energy social services i.e. solar lanterns, solar powered street lights completed for 2016 where 800 household solar units and 2 solar market places will be powered with solar energy. - Procurement process for supply, delivery and installation of solar energy systems completed to provide solar energy systems to 20 health units and 20 schools

comment.narrative: Around 18.8 million people in need of livelihoods support, including access to income opportunities and key essential services â€“ including 10.3 million in acute needs (2017)

- Launching the project activities and recruitment of project staff - Needs assessment conducted to identify the health facilities that need rehabilitation and solar equipment. - Needs assessment carried out to identify the targeted districts for cash for work , sub-projets are identified and direct beneficiaries are enrolled in CFW and asset upgrade. - Damage Assessments conducted by VCCs and DMTs.

The project has been launched successfully during the 3rd quarter and LOA was finalized with the implementing partner (SFD). Preparation for the needs assessments for the identification of health facilities and targeted districts for cash for work is ongoing. Recruitment of project staff is ongoing
